reviewText:
The Evil Within is perhaps one of the best third person survival horror games in years. The game feels very much like a natural extension of Mikami’s Resident Evil 4, mainly focusing on tense encounters while managing a limited set of resources. Not content to be a simple retread, The Evil Within also goes some way into subverting and challenging many of the conventions set up by Resident Evil 4.

Most strikingly, The Evil Within rarely lets the player feel “safe”. Many of the moves in the game offer little to no invincible frames; the player may be hit out of a stealth kill or trying to burn a downed enemy at almost any time. Gone is the relatively safe pattern of shooting an enemy in the kneecap then running up and suplexing him into his buddies found in Resident Evil 4. Instead the player must use caution in just about every part of a combat situation. This also applies to hit animations; at least once this reviewer was caught in a stun animation from a trap explosion only to fall into a boss’ instant kill move.

The feeling of vulnerability extends to the player’s movement. Whereas Resident Evil 6 may have perfected movement mechanics in terms of player empowerment (perhaps too much so), the Evil Within keeps the player purposefully limited. Sebastian can only sprint in a limited duration, before upgrades, and exhausting his endurance meter leaves him winded and vulnerable. Similarly, there is no dodge mechanic. In addition, melee (before acquiring an unlockable item) is largely unsuitable for kills. This further forces the player to manage encounters in a more thoughtful manner than rolling around and chaining melee combos.

Items tend to be scarce within in the game. Even if the player finds themselves with a surplus through stealth killing their way through a chapter, a particularly rough, or botched, encounter may find them strapped for resources. The Evil Within manages to make missed shots feel painful in a way very few recent games have. This is reinforced by the fact that Sebastian is no crack shot; even fully upgraded his aim has a sway that demands the player slow themselves a bit to ensure each bullet hits its mark.  Sebastian also tends to be fragile; making each syringe count. Medkits are also available, in limited supply (the first play through provided perhaps only five or six), but the use of one puts Sebastian in a delirious, defenseless, state.

The Evil Within also delivers atmosphere in spades. The entire game has the feel of an ever shifting nightmare. Horrific traps, a village reminiscent of Resident Evil 4, a homage to the mansion in the original Resident Evil, and bizzarely twisted cityscapes are some of the vistas awaiting the player. Given the constantly changing landscape the player is always given a different set of challenges. The positive side being that if one happened to dislike something in a chapter the chances of seeing it again are slim to none; The Evil Within is rarely in the habit of repeating itself.

The Agony Crossbow is a weapon that deserves special mention. While each weapon in the game looks, sounds, and handles superbly with satisfying gore effects the crossbow brings something special to the equation. Each weapon has a place and fits a roll, the Agony Crossbow, with its selection of bolts, gives the player a multitude of options. If unsure of a situation the crossbow is often the way to go, from setting traps, stunning enemies or simple raw firepower the weapon has an answer even if bolts are painfully limited.

The story may feel a bit disjointed and vague. That said it does feel very intentional. The model viewer, available after beating the game, in particular offers some insight into just what all the creatures happen to be. The player is never spoon-fed anything (no information dumps, bright glowing arrows, or so on). Rather, the feeling of bewilderment seems completely intended. The game mechanics also put quite a bit of faith in the player’s intelligence which is satisfying given the current trend in games. What may have seen like trial and error deaths were likely completely avoidable if one were paying attention; the clues simply weren’t painted in neon.

The game isn’t without issues. It is susceptible to crashes (the ones this reviewer ran into where exclusive to chapters three and four and seemingly random). In addition, pre-patch, the game was limited to thirty frames per second and black bars. During this play through I favored sixty frames per second with the black bars, to play as closely to Mikami’s vision as possible (I also rather liked them after a time). The Evil Within features some rough spots as it clearly did not enjoy the budget or time Mikami had with Resident Evil 4. That said, it is still an excellent survival horror game; perhaps one of the best examples of third person horror in years. Well worth the time and money.

reviewText:
The Evil WIthin!  From the mind of Shinji Mikami (so you know it's going to be crazy!)  Wiki him if you don't know who he is, has a long list of games to his name.  The title of the game should be a pretty big hint at what type of game this is.  I haven't played Silent Hill but I think it's more of a Silent Hill game than Resident Evil.

Overall I enjoyed the game, I'm going to break it down:
Story: Erm, well this is sort of hard.  This is probably the weakest part for me.  I feel like you have to connect a lot of dots to figure out what's going on.  I read some impressions from other people after I finished it that helped me do that.  Neat story, but could have been done better I think.  Have more tape recordings (are found during the game) or something to give a little more back story.

Gameplay: I play games like this in a really percise manner.  Enemies at the start won't die by a single head shot, there can be hidden enemies, there are traps all around and your ammo is limited.  Therefore I go through pretty slow, used stealth as much as I could (stealth kills are 1 hit KO) and thought stuff out a lot as I went to be as efficient as I could be.  You have a number of weapons that you upgrade through the game, the gunplay is very good as is using stealth.  My first play through was ~15 hours w/ 33 deaths, even being percise you will die a lot!

Audio/Video: Graphics are fantastic (using an i5/780).  There were some perfomrance issues when it first came out but a few patches in on the PC version have fixed a lot of issues and made performance a lot better.  The game tries to unhinge you.  They'll be lots of blood, eerie sounds and what not.  The name of the game is Evil Within, you should expect this!  The game isn't really scary, there are a few jump scares, but it's very tense.

Other: First time through I unlocked some new weapons and they gave me a lot of green gel to level up skills if I want to go back in so it seems like there is good replay value (similar to RE4) if you like the game.  If you like Mikami games, horror games, or a good 3rd person shooting game (with crazy/horror/weird style)I would say it's worth a play through!

reviewText:
I hate Ruvik, I hate Kidman, I hate Leslie and most of all, I hate Joseph.

The Evil Within is supposed to be survival horror game but is actually a survival-action game. First on the launch it had 30 FPS lock and Black bar problem, and with latest patch it's fixed, thank god. But , still the game lots of good points and lots of bad points.
Starting with good points, when Shinji Mikami wants it, he gives you good taste of horror with game's ambient, unknown psyhological stuff and abominations that haunt you and make you suffer both physically and mentally. What made me wanna finish this game, is that I had to record for my channel, my curiosity for the ending and that I wanted to see both Ruvik and Joseph suffering. I had fun in boss fights, such as Luna , The Keeper etc. They were not like Re4's head-on combat, but hide'N Seek, save your bullets and run for your life , combat. And last but not least, the ambient, the areas of the game were quite interresting. You would have no idea where you'll end up in next chapter or even after some minutes. And in every corner, there is a trap that wants to say hello to you! Beware.
Bad Points? A lot.First of all, I hated and raged a lot during Chapter 11-12-13 . Why ? Cause this fricking game turns into CoD Evil Warfare. Monsters attacking you with Heavy Machine Guns, Smg's and Molotovs. I am sorry but , this not how a survival horror game supposed to be. I am sorry , but this is where ♥♥♥♥ hits the fan. I was really enjoying the dark ambient of The Evil Within, then game threw me somewhere, where I stand on a lift and all of those monster were throwing molotovs at me and shooting like 12 year old CoD Player. Thats when I was fed up with this game and Mikami's love of Zombie-using-SMGs. That's easy, cheap and disgusting and I am sorry , but not survival horror game.
I would recommend you to buy this game, only on it's sale or you really really really like Resident Evil 4. For Horror game lovers, this game is not meant to be guys, I am sorry.

But still, 10/10 would curse to Joseph and Shinji Mikami while playing, with joy.

reviewText:
Return of the horror in gaming, after Resident Evil completely drained it out.
It kinda worked.
As soon as you start the game you will notice, that the game is clearly a console port.
Mouse in menus feels odd and kind of unresponsive, the default settings are at 30 FPS with black borders. After a patch, you can turn 60 FPS on, disable border. Best get rid of motion blur as well. It's playable in the game that way, unless you try using more AA than the cheap console FXAA (AA wannabe more like), otherwise FPS drop down horribly.

In the actual game, the controlls feel ok - and that's what is important.
The game, while not terribly scary, does create a constant feel of suspense. Beeing carefull is what this game is about.
I wouldn't even touch the casual mode, survival is not that hard anyway, so if you are wondering which to start on - don't :)

Game is heavily story-based, it is not open, but rather a series of corridors/pathways with bigger areas you can explore from most angles. Despite beeing a horror game, you kill a lot of enemies here. All the pickups are capped pretty low before you upgrade them, so you can't exactly go trigger happy. Instead, you sneak kill as much as you can. While avoiding is possible, it doesn't really pay off.
Upgrades are made thanks to the green goo you collect. Weapons, ammo capacity, health, sprint - that kind of things.

Graphics are not the most spectacular, but than again - better than Resident Evil 6 for example.

Overall a good game. I'd give it an 8/10.

reviewText:
Alright so this game has some technical problems when it comes to the screenratio, fps and stuff. But I'd like to say that so far, this has been one of the most horryfying game experiences I've experienced ever. For me the start was kinda dull and lame (except the chainsaw chase), and the story seemed pretty generic and bland to begin with. But suddenly stuff starts to happen all the time, the game just gets worse and gives you less time to recover.

There are also several interesting enemies with cool (although a bit over the top gory) models. I'd like to say that Laura is the worst thing I've ever layed my eyes upon. The gameplay is also fun and interesting, although it can be repetive in some cases. The atmosphere is perfect, the music/sound effects is also very good!

I'd recommend this game for you if you're able to see past this games' technical flaws (some of them can almost be fully fixed using commands) and if you like to get stressed/anxious 24/7. Some stuff in here might be cheesy as hell, but whatever, it's a lot scarier than Outlast in my opinion. And don't even get me started on how this game bends reality and messes up your brain.

Though I have to say that I've never played any RE or SH game myself, so maybe this terrifies me so much because it's a new experience for me. Neither did I follow this game's development for long. I found out the day before it released that ''HEY this looks cool in a messed up way!''

Guns does not equal safe  (especially not if Laura is after you!)

reviewText: The Evil within is a good game with a good story. However I cannot recommend it . This game is brutally difficult. Don’t get me wrong I’m all for a challenge, but when I sit down to play a game I want something that’s fun and fulfilling, not an experience that leaves me ripping my hair out and wanting to quit. Being forced to run from invincible enemies through an entire level is not a fun gameplay mechanic and if it weren’t for the obnoxious number of times which I’m forced to do so, I might actually enjoy the game. In fact when I’m not fleeing from my undefeatable enemy I am enjoying myself.  Searching through the creepy and very well done level design for ammo, collectables and keys for upgrades is a very fun experience. But it all goes down the tube when u face off against an enemy which you simply cannot defeat. It leaves you feeling like all the upgrades and perks where for nothing because now you’re forced to run away regardless of how much experience you dumped into your health bar.\nI understand that the invincible enemy is supposed to be scary, u cant kill it so u have to think your way around them instead of going in bullets blazing. However the game simply dose it far too often. It becomes tedious, frustrating and boring.  Once again, I cannot recommend this game.\n

reviewText:
Your typical AAA title nowadays - good graphics, awful game in every other way.

My brother purchased this for me as a birthday gift. We have played a good few hours together now and I have concluded that the game is somewhat enjoyable. Not because it's a good game, however, but because it is absolutely hilarious to witness such sh*t.

The story:

Absolutely ridiculous story with incredibly boring characters. At the beginning of the game, after visiting an asylum, you leave to find what looks like the beginning of an apocalypse. Buildings are on fire and sh*t and there is even one of those giant cracks in the earth (I have no idea what they're called, but its used in loads of those stupid action/thriller movies). The story is just so far fetched that I assume the entire story happened in his imagination (I am yet to finish the game). Nevertheless, the devastatingly bad story does have its advantage as it provides several hilarious and cringy moments for you to laugh at.

The voice acting:

All of the voice acting is atrocious and extremely bland. There is no character development at all and the character you play as sounds way too calm, considering the situation. Also, the script is extremely amusing because it is, like the story, awful.

The gameplay:

Your character, despite being in the police force and, therefore, having completed demanding physical endurance tests, can run for about 2 seconds before stopping to catch a breather. Literally 2 seconds. This is not an exaggeration. However, fortunately for him, he can teleport through magic mirrors that take him to a hospital ward with an electric chair that injects green sh*t into his brain. He willingly chooses to take part in this process. After all, this injection of green filth directly into the brain can produce additional clothing pockets that can store extra ammo. Also, his stamina can be increased so that he can run for a remarkable 4 or 5 seconds without stopping.

In addition to this, the combat is appalling. Did you know that you can shoot half of an enemy's brain out with a weapon of your choice and he will continue to show signs of perfect cognitive ability. Well... I take that back. At times the enemies will run straight past you and stand around in a corner for a while. Also, the melee combat with bare fists consists of punching the enemy twice, then running away as he swings a really powerful backhander at you. Rinse and repeat that process about 3 or 4 times and you kill him.

Conclusion:

A bad game that's only real positive aspect is the comedy that can be found in its flaws.

recommended:
and it's a pretty cool concept.
The game runs smoothly but unfortunatley has no support (or any signs of upcoming support) for muilti-GPU configurations so I would recommend having a high end single GPU for ultra graphics. If not though your probably only missing out on better shadow/reflection effects.This game also features a very unusal widescreen aspect ratio which puts two big black bars on the top and bottom of the screen. This can be altered by hitting the "insert" button and typing the following:
R_forceaspectratio 1.88
Also to unlock the frame rate:
R_swapinterval 0
Using these console commands will make the game look much more normal and you'll be having fun in no time. Forewarning though

reviewText:
Disclaimer: I picked this game up after all the first major patch which seemed to clear up bugs/FPS locks/black bars on the game. I only hit one bug in an entire play through that I noticed.

The game is completely bat ♥♥♥♥ crazy and fantastic. Not had this much fun in a resident evil styled game in quite some time. A couple of jumpscares in the game but pretty much it's dead space styled 'horror'.

The first chapter/demo is so weird compared to the rest as it's a hidey/sneaky fest whereas the rest of the game involves murdering all the baddies with various weaponry.

The game is pretty much resident evil and hellraiser mashed up, if you aren't a fan of barbed wire and brains (not intelligence, actual brain matter) then it's likely not for you.

It's decently long (12 ish hours on first play through on 'survivor ala normal' - it has a new game + mode and like resident evil it has loads of extra stupid op weapons to play it through again.

Only real downsides I found was that the characters are pretty wooden/unintersting as is your characters back story. The main story though is nuts and ends up working like some horror version of Inception so more than made up for it.
It's definately one of those 'is this reality or a dream' styled affairs. My only other gripe is that some 'bosses' were overused at points and were plain irritating.

Nuts and bolts wise, game ran silky smooth at full whack (1920x1080) controls never felt like they were letting me down, mouse and keyboard all the way through was no issues at all or alternative xbox controller setup is available. Music and overall sound effects were sublime at points, there are quite a few 'story' bits you wander through and the sound/music was really atmospheric. Game length was pitched about right, not too long as it would get boring or too short that you thought 'where did the game go'.

If you like the things I've mentioned, go for it - worth every penny and I'm seriously weight up a second playthrough and if a sequel appears it will be on my wishlist faster than you can see drilled nail into the frontal lobe of the brain on a live subject to drain blood from a machine and open up a weird multi locking door in a haunted mansion. (Yes that happens...)

reviewText:
Let me start  of on a negative note: The Evil Within's voice acting is laughably bad. Granted, the original Japanese voice work could very well be a nuanced, or at the very least, passable affair. Not being a Japanese language speaker, this is sadly a perspective I'll never be privy to.

That said, Evil Within's [english language] voice work is almost a non-issue, as the piece's tonal strengths and atmosphere are masterfully delivered through a slavish devotion to aural and visual craftsmanship. The lighting is incredibly dynamic, shifting and warping organically. The same can be said about EW's soundscape; whether it be the nerve-rattling soundtrack or near unbearable haunts of silence, the game's phonic presence lends itself perfectly to the nightmarish journey at hand.

Gameplay-wise, anyone familiar with the likes of Resident Evil 4 and beyond will be right at home. Shinji Mikami and Co. once again struck a near perfect balance between keeping the game's mechanics tight and enjoyable, while never giving the player enough breathing room to ever feel comfortable or overpowered. Resource management is crucial, especially on the harder difficulties.

I found the game optimization reasonable (infuriating launch-day shortfalls notwithstanding). Rigged with 2 Nvidia 680M's and an Intel i7 3940xm (3.9ghz OC'ed), the game ran fairly smooth at 30fps at Ultra settings. However, removing the letterbox, which adds an additional 30% of screen real estate to the GPU's workload, caused noticable lag spikes. I recommend anyone facing performance inconsistencies to utilize  Nvidia Inspector and its extensive array of customization options and game profiles.

Highly recommend to any fan of survival horror gameplay with an action-centric slant. A small measure of RPG-based character modification also adds to the game's tension, encouraging the player to trail off the beaten path, in hopes of collecting the ever precious Green Gel" (the game's version of upgrade currency)."

reviewText:
Let me start  of on a negative note: The Evil Within's voice acting is laughably bad. Granted, the original Japanese voice work could very well be a nuanced, or at the very least, passable affair. Not being a Japanese language speaker, this is sadly a perspective I'll never be privy to.

That said, Evil Within's [english language] voice work is almost a non-issue, as the piece's tonal strengths and atmosphere are masterfully delivered through a slavish devotion to aural and visual craftsmanship. The lighting is incredibly dynamic, shifting and warping organically. The same can be said about EW's soundscape; whether it be the nerve-rattling soundtrack or near unbearable haunts of silence, the game's phonic presence lends itself perfectly to the nightmarish journey at hand.

Gameplay-wise, anyone familiar with the likes of Resident Evil 4 and beyond will be right at home. Shinji Mikami and Co. once again struck a near perfect balance between keeping the game's mechanics tight and enjoyable, while never giving the player enough breathing room to ever feel comfortable or overpowered. Resource management is crucial, especially on the harder difficulties.

I found the game optimization reasonable (infuriating launch-day shortfalls notwithstanding). Rigged with 2 Nvidia 680M's and an Intel i7 3940xm (3.9ghz OC'ed), the game ran fairly smooth at 30fps at Ultra settings. However, removing the letterbox, which adds an additional 30% of screen real estate to the GPU's workload, caused noticable lag spikes. I recommend anyone facing performance inconsistencies to utilize  Nvidia Inspector and its extensive array of customization options and game profiles.

Highly recommend to any fan of survival horror gameplay with an action-centric slant. A small measure of RPG-based character modification also adds to the game's tension, encouraging the player to trail off the beaten path, in hopes of collecting the ever precious Green Gel" (the game's version of upgrade currency)."

reviewText:
The Evil Within is one of the most frustrating and also most rewarding horror games to hit the PC since the dawn of time. When the game first came out, I absolutely hated it and if I reviewed it then, I'd have never recommended people buy it, let alone play it. However, multiple patches later, 60fps and removal of the black bars opened up a gaming experience which is the closest thing to Resident Evil 4 that you can get so far.

Having said that, in my opinion, the first 3 chapters are a bit lack luster, with annoyingly forced scenes where you have to flee, mixed with the TERRIBLE accuracy of the starting weapon, the pistol. This leads to a very frustrating experience, as mentioned previously. The lack of ammo (its a survival horror so this is expected) would be fine if the pistol didn't have a 5 degree cone of accuracy on it to start with, which means you never get rewarded for accuracy. This takes a lot of skill away from the player sadly, which lets the game down.

HOWEVER, chapter 4 onwards is like playing a different game. The first real horror experience for me was in chapter 4 with Laura"
date: who is the best and worst of Japanese horror cliches merged into one creature. The game then sets you up right after that moment with an equally bad part
recommended:
literally throwing you out of the hot frying pan and into the fire. This is the pace the game then continues with for the majority of its 15 chapters.

PROS
+ closest game to Resident Evil 4 in terms of approach and style
+ Interesting story
+ nice setting
+ impressive visuals
+ genuinely hard encounters
+ INSANE level of difficulty if you're brave enough...

CONS
- Still needs a very powerful machine to run it properly
- "Boss" creatures aren't explained and you have to repeatedly die whilst learning their mechanics
- Storyline isn't explained at all

Towards the end it becomes less scary and more concerning as you run our of ammo and start facing multiple enemies in quick succession.  It also results in the game being a lot less fun and before you know it you are just racing for the finish line!

7/10 only because I feel it fell a bit short and became repetative in the second half of the game.  Still a good survival horror tho.

reviewText:
Become Sebastian Castellanos, police detective. He needs to unravel the elaborate mind-bending mystery of a small village because...uh...all part of the job.

Gameplay:

The beginning of the game was, I suspect, heavily influenced by Resident Evil 4. The experiences are cut and paste. Things get shaken up later on, though. Minus points for originality, I'm satisfied with the gameplay. I am beginning to wonder if we're trying too hard to depict horrible parodies of human life. After a certain point, it becomes ridiculous.

Story:

At first, this story made me downright angry. Early game, there are many moments that it fails to capitalize on, narratively speaking. Early on, the story fails to provide stable footing. We aren't able to orient ourselves until much later in the game. Characters make strange decisions for seemingly no reason. Many of them respond to the hideous events in strange ways. Expect liberal amounts of deus ex machina to move the plot along.

I bought this in the sale and would never pay so much for a game at it's full price.

reviewText:
The Evil Within is one of the most frustrating and also most rewarding horror games to hit the PC since the dawn of time. When the game first came out, I absolutely hated it and if I reviewed it then, I'd have never recommended people buy it, let alone play it. However, multiple patches later, 60fps and removal of the black bars opened up a gaming experience which is the closest thing to Resident Evil 4 that you can get so far.

Having said that, in my opinion, the first 3 chapters are a bit lack luster, with annoyingly forced scenes where you have to flee, mixed with the TERRIBLE accuracy of the starting weapon, the pistol. This leads to a very frustrating experience, as mentioned previously. The lack of ammo (its a survival horror so this is expected) would be fine if the pistol didn't have a 5 degree cone of accuracy on it to start with, which means you never get rewarded for accuracy. This takes a lot of skill away from the player sadly, which lets the game down.

HOWEVER, chapter 4 onwards is like playing a different game. The first real horror experience for me was in chapter 4 with Laura"

reviewText:
A severely underrated and overlooked survival horror game. Strikes a delicate balance between making the player helpless and overpowering the player. Graphically, it's quite pleasing, and the art style is top notch if you like Silent hill and Resident Evil. The psychological horror elements are well-executed, and very cinematic. A cross between Dead Space, Resident Evil, Bethesda's Call of Cthulhu and Silent Hill.

Graphics: 8/10 A little dated this long after release, but overall good textures, lighting, DOF and quality

Sound: 9/10 Spooky, well-mixed and atmospheric. The sounds of enemies allow you to differentiate between the types and plan accordingly, while your sounds can and will give your position away.

Plot: 7.5/10 A little contrived, and not the most original. However, the air of mystery is quite nice.

Overall, I loved it

Bought the bundle, an easy 9/10.

Obviously, for those that know, Shinji Mikami worked on this, so the first appeal to it, is that it feels like a third person classic Resident Evil game. (Think RE0, with more scare factor.)

The atmosphere is spot on. I died multiple times on the very first chapter, because I got scared sh*tless and didn't move fast enough. 10/10 would get my head chainsaw'd off again.

I heard stuff about the game being locked at 30FPS before, and that you couldn't play the game in fullscreen. Those problems were addressed, and now you can play the game in 30 or 60FPS, and in fullscreen. I highly suggest putting the film grain effect down to 50%, as it can be quite annoying sometimes.

Overall, 9/10.

reviewText:
The Evil Within is an old-school survival horror by the creator of Resident Evil: playing as Detective Castellanos as you try to survive the various nightmarish places and enemies put in front of you is quite fun overall but sadly its old-school roots can sometimes get in the way of your enjoyment.

PROS:

-the art style of the places and creatures you'll meet is exquisitely surreal and disturbing

-the game mantains an eerie and dreadful atmosphere for its whole length

-memorable antagonist

-good sound design

-the survival aspect is well executed, enemies can be quite damaging and come at you suddendly or in waves, ammo and health items are never plentiful forcing you to rely on stealth kills/distractions

-provides a good challenge even on its basic difficulty level

-overall story is pretty interesting and engaging

-the upgrade system for weapons and skills works nicely and lets you customize your character to fit your playstyle

-good length

NEUTRAL:

-certain enemies, mini-bosses and bosses with instakill moves can be annoying for some players

-the game progressively shifts from horror/stealth sections to more action/combat oriented scenes and this might not sit well with everyone

CONS:

-clunky controls for fine movements and aiming, expecially with a controller

-graphics are a bit too washed out and shadows can be, at times, way too saturated in black: there's also some noticeable texture pop-in

-there's some weird mouse acceleration in menus, mouse wheel was also never fixed and so can't be used in them

-while interesting the story is a bit too cryptic for its own good

-having to break countless boxes/jars to gather items gets boring fast and also detracts from the overall atmosphere

-having to go back and forth to the savegame hub (accessible through mirrors scattered around levels) to save, upgrade or open lockers gets annoying in the long run

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=495092217

The Evil Within is truly a throwback to the good old days of the survival horror genre and it provides a good experience overall with a strong (albeit cloudy) story, disturbing enemies, challenging boss fights, collectibles, a good amount of weapons and several upgrades to choose from.

Its old-school roots also mar the experience a bit though, movement is clunky, fine aiming (even with a fully upgraded weapon) can be a bit off at times and the fact you are required to pull off headshots most of the time- while evading enemies trying to grab you- can make things frustrating at times. It can also get a bit aggravating on certain bosses, where you have to dodge their moves and then frantically try and adjust your aim to fire properly without wasting too many shots.

But persistence in the face of certain design faults is rewarded by one of the most enjoyable horror experiences I've had this year and, while The Evil Within isn't the masterwork that Resident Evil was, it's nonetheless a quite good game that survival horror fans'd have in their library.

I can’t say that I’ve felt compelled to leave any type of review for any of the games that I own, but I just had to leave one for this game. I am always in search for a good horror games, and I can honestly say that I thoroughly enjoyed The Evil Within. I did purchase this game and the expansions during the Steam Summer Sale, but it is well worth the money I paid, and then some. All in all, well worth my money.

Oh yeah, expect a LOT of gore and blood. Easily one of the bloodiest I’ve played in a while. I’ll rate it a 9/10. Enjoy, my friends.

If you love WTF situations, WTF stories and WTF monsters, this game is for you.
It's a mind ♥♥♥♥, so expect your mind to be ♥♥♥♥ed.

The STORY: It's probably not the best, but it's a nice one. Takes time to understand what's going on, where you are, where you go. But eventually I ended up loving it.

The COMBAT: You need a decent computer to play this. I had to upgrade my old ♥♥♥♥ to be able to play without any lag. I had no issue then, everything was fluid, beautiful and complex. You upgrade your brain...to upgrade your weapon. It's a mind ♥♥♥♥ game remember? The green goo is your friend. You can craft, upgrade some weapons, abilities, ammunitions. I really enjoyed that. Combat system itself is efficient, you can hide, stealth and you are human...you can't have a ridiculous amount of ammunitions with you, which makes the game more interesting tactic-wise. You wait for the right moment to shoot, etc.

The GRAPHICS: I really love them. The explosion of zombies, blood and brains can look ridiculous but I don't care. I freaking love it. I love the monsters, I love the creepy areas, I love the gore effects, I love the traps.

I am scared quite easily if I set up the right mood, and I had a bunch of scares and heart race while playing the game. Streaming it live did help getting scared even more sometimes!

I will play it again in a while, and hopefully I'll forget most of it so I can enjoy it a second time!

As far as BUGS go, the only slight issue I encountered with this game is sometimes the textures on certain models would fail to render right away but then they would appear a few moments after. Specifically on some of the bosses I had to fight with slimy tentacles and limbs. No map textures or anything like that. As far as everything else the game was smooth as butter with the 60fps cap at the highest settings and it NEVER once crashed on me. I did not meet the requirements even. FIGHTING the zombies was not as epic as I had imagined considering how scary they looked. The encounters were rather predictable and repetitive which consisted of: Melee back up avoid the counter attack/flailing arms or weapons" then melee again repeat 5 or 6 times till their head magically explodes or just shoot them a couple of times as they walk up to you slowly. If they charge you take a few steps out the way.

The A.I wasn't that challenging as they would sometimes run up against picket fences and walls and the gun play itself wasn't very intense or as satisfying as RE4. You might shoot something every once in a while if you had ammo but rationing resources was kind of forced on you. The one thing I absoluted HATED about this game was the stamina feature. Anytime you run out of the few seconds of sprinting stamina you had

reviewText:
Pros:
+Gradually opens up into something resembling a more modern Resident Evil 4.
+Interesting antagonist & story premise, once it eventually decides to slightly explain itself.
+RPG-like character-building encourages exploration & killing avoidable, difficult enemies
+Beautiful graphics in certain places
+Not necessarily scary for the most part, but maintains a consistently high level of tension throughout

Cons:
-Been there, done or seen an older version of that.
-You're in a forest village of sorts. Poof, now you're in a sewer with basically no explanation whatsoever as to how you got there. Better get used to a lack of context. It's really bothersome in that it makes it difficult to rationalize pushing forwards at times.
-Poorly told story. It has potential and a fair amount of depth to it, but you get drips of narrative at a time until well over halfway through the game and by then the vagueness that remains isn't at all justified. It's DLC baiting, really.
-Poorly fleshed-out characters. I still like 'em and all, but there could have been much more there. Not much to go on in the character development department, really.
-Enemy variety, or the lack thereof. 99% zombies of the typical weapon-wielding type.
-Poorly optimized for PC. Good luck keeping a consistent 60 FPS; my GTX 980 didn't manage it in places.
-FRUSTRATION. There's a Dark Souls level of difficulty to specific scenarios in the game, only you can generally blame poor design and a lack of timely checkpoints for your many deaths while dealing with her rather than your own mistakes.
-Gore isn't scary in and of itself, apparently. Even if you turn it up to 11 or 11,000 or beyond, as The Evil Within does.

In case this isn't TL;DR already:

Sprint time: 4.0 seconds. Early on you'll be surrounded by zombies, and this is what you've got to work with. Exceed those four seconds of slowly-recovering sprint time and your character will stop moving and gasp for air for *several* seconds, regardless of how imminent the nearest zombie's ax is to his head. Factor in the facts that melee attacks are nearly useless, you've very little ammunition (if any) and your character's aiming abilities are informed mostly by apparent alcoholism, and it's safe to say you're incredibly weak and vulnerable at the beginning of the game.

You'll gradually grow stronger, sure, but initially you're going to be looking at a lot of frustration due to protagonist Sebastian's generally not being an unrealistic badass. Unfortunately, this frustration will keep showing up later on in the game when you're facing certain poorly-designed bosses; there's no way to really kill her in a particular encounter, for example, and if anything the real offender here is the checkpoint system. You're guaranteed to die in certain scenarios at least a few times, and the checkpoint system has no apparent logic regarding when and where to kick in.

Aside from the frustration factor I generally enjoyed the game, but damn if it didn't nearly cripple it at points. Buyer beware, but I'd recommend it on sale, if you think you can handle an initially contextless, very difficult Resident Evil 4 with some frustrating points hampering an otherwise good (but not especially great) experience.

Also, upgrade the crossbow and invest in full upgrades to harpoon bolts. It helps.

reviewText:
I liked the first half of the game and initially had a positive review, but it got bad pretty fast.

It gets bad in the second half of the game. Some examples:
-See an enemy standing next to a lever out in the open.
-He's obviously going to open the cage of enemies next to him, or trigger a trap.
-Shoot the guy before he pulls the lever.
-The guy is INVINSIBLE and you have to let him pull the lever.

It feels pretty cheap, especially when you have a scope aimed at his head.
There are a lot of other frustrating moments as well that I TRIED to overlook, but there's so MANY of them. It gets to the point where you just face palm and stop having fun.

Evil Within had a decent story going and could have taken this game anywhere. They aren't limited by realism and could have got creative thanks to the plot. But when you're standing in the open daylight, with a bunch of the same enemies in a cage, and a guy standing next to a lever that you can't kill.... It's just laziness.

Not worth the 38GB download. Don't waste your time.

reviewText:
For the gore-hounds out there, this game delivers. If you're looking something truly scary, you might be better off looking elsewhere. If you want a deep story that makes you consider the dark horrors lurking in the human mind, don't play this game.

Overall, this game is a mixed bag of nuts. It seems like the developers didn't really know what they wanted to do and wound up just throwing everything into the batter and hoping the cake came out okay. At some points, this game is scary, at some points it's laughably stupid; some points are very fun, others are ridiculously frustrating. It's not a bad game, but it's definitely not a good game. I enjoyed it and definitely thought it was worth the 20 bucks or so I paid for it. The only thing that is irredeemable is the story, but I won't spoil it for you as to why I think the story was that bad.

reviewText:
I ended up loving The Evil Within way more than I thought I would. It turned out to be one of the coolest games I've ever played.

The visual designs of the environments, the enemies, it's all absolutely incredible and the way you are just thrown around all these different places and situations feels like something you really only could pull off in a video game.
The game keeps a wonderful pace throughout it's lengthy runtime, always mixing up shooting and stealth and never letting you feel overpowered - you will always be on the edge of your seat. It's a very difficult game (and some sections can be pretty frustrating to get through, although I personally enjoy these kinds of challenges) and it thrives on tension - if you're not playing this in a darkened room with headphones, you're doing it wrong. The excellent sound design gives life to the repulsive, insane and wonderfully creative imagery.

The DLC is excellent too and a great companion to the main story - the excellent and character-driven plot (which admittedly took me a while to really get into in the main game) is made more clear, while new elements are introduced to the gameplay to keep it fresh. There's also plenty of extra challenges by way of MANY achievements and well hidden collectibles if that floats your boat.

All in all, I struggle to understand why this is only rated Mostly Positive" on Steam. I seriously think it's amazing and extremely engaging."

reviewText:
When I had heard about this game I was beyond excited for it. Everything about it just sounded so amazing.

When the game finally came out I couldn't really buy it so I waited. Eventually a friend bought it for me as a gift and I had been playing it on and off since around Christmas time. I instantly fell in love with the game. At first the game did scare me, I will admit. So I would play for short periods, but after the initial shock of the jump scares and other things, I just got into the game and played through it.

There were some parts of the game that were rather annoying because the controls can sometimes be clunky when you're playing a third person game. But putting those minor bugs aside the only real issue I had was following along with the story at the end of the game.

The ending was probably the only real confusing part for me, it was fairly vague and for me I'm not huge on that. I like figuring things out, but I also like having some useful clues too.

All-in-all it is a GREAT game and a must play for anyone who has enjoyed Resident Evil and probably Silent Hill as well, or even survival horror as a whole. It is a great game and definitely worth the time to play it. (I beat it in about 12.5 hours with a bit of extra exploring).

reviewText:
The Evil Within has accomplished what it set out to do, to be a true survival horror game that harkens back to the likes of RE4. Shinji Mikami knows RE4 was his greatest achievement, a true revolutionary title and its clear when playing this, a lot is taken from RE4 with some modern mechanics to boot. I'm not gonna lie, there were a few times I felt like chucking my controller in frustration, this game isn't easy. I died 39 times over the 16 hour campaign and thats supposed to be pretty good compared to most. Ammo is truly scarce in this game, so the added stealth kill mechanic should always be your first line of attack.

I would love tell you the story is good but well I'm not really sure if it is. Its certainly starts off interesting but it clearly doesn't want to explain itself, by the end it just leaves you with too many questions, which normally would be good but since I don't have proper answers, I'm left with what seem to be plot-holes which make no sense.

If you're going into this expecting a revolutionary survival horror game like RE4 was back in 2005, you're going be disappointed but if you go into it expecting something like RE4, more old school survival horror with most of the difficulty and clunkiness intact. I'm sure you'll have a great time, albeit with moments of frustration along the way.

reviewText:
The graphics aren’t exactly state of the art, but the game definitely doesn’t need those looks, it looks just right for this game and that makes them excellent. Also, the 5.1 sound is wonderful.

Sure, the game is not perfectly optimized. But I feel that that technical grittiness enhances the horror and grittiness of the game as a whole, so I’m really okay with that. The aspect ratio is, just as the game, brutal. It didn’t bother me at all, I actually think it enhances the game.

There’s some cheap scares in the game which is disappointing. Mostly the gore of the first couple of chapters. It does set the mood though, it forces the atmosphere on the player from the start so in that respect it works great, and the game is very tense overall.

The game is like a wonderful mix of Resident Evil 4, Silent Hill and also with a pinch of Siren. Unfortunately it’s easy to make comparison to the Saw series of movies as well.

The story kept me interested throughout and I wanted to see it through to the end. Great B-horror story with a lot of body horror thrown in!

Unfortunately the last chapter suffers from, what I see as, design flaws. I kept running low and sometimes even out of ammo. Instead of restarting the chapter I used the console command to give me infinite ammo at one point, which I’m not happy about. Hopefully they can fix this in a patch.

Towards the end of the game you get in some gauntlet type situations. I rarely feel that these are necessary and/or fun, but I do understand that they are put there to act as a catharsis for the player after the otherwise tense experience.

Some of the bosses border more on the annoying and tedious, I’m mostly referring to the returning boss in chapter ten. Tension is definitely lost when you die and have to redo a section a dozen times.

Overall a really great game. If there wouldn’t have been another Resident Evil after #4, and ten years later a ”spiritual successor” was released, this would most definitely be it.

The story kept me interested throughout and I wanted to see it through to the end. Great B-horror story with a lot of body horror thrown in!

Unfortunately the last chapter suffers from, what I see as, design flaws. I kept running low and sometimes even out of ammo. Instead of restarting the chapter I used the console command to give me infinite ammo at one point, which I’m not happy about. Hopefully they can fix this in a patch.

Towards the end of the game you get in some gauntlet type situations. I rarely feel that these are necessary and/or fun, but I do understand that they are put there to act as a catharsis for the player after the otherwise tense experience.

Some of the bosses border more on the annoying and tedious, I’m mostly referring to the returning boss in chapter ten. Tension is definitely lost when you die and have to redo a section a dozen times.

Overall a really great game. If there wouldn’t have been another Resident Evil after #4, and ten years later a ”spiritual successor” was released, this would most definitely be it.

reviewText:
Plagued with awful design choices, technical mishaps and crashes, and a practically non-existent plot (or a plot that might as well not exist). Anything and everything in this game can be an instant death trap, even with all health upgrades. The game has an incredibly frustrating habit of changing the rules or adding new mechanics and then instantly killing the player for his lack of clairvoyance.

Unfortunately, this is aggravated by the lengthy pre-scripted, inescapable death animations and the awful checkpoint system which ensures that you get set back as far back as half an hour before the point that killed you. Only about half the time that I died was I completely sure of what had killed me, or had any idea of what to do to escape death the second time around.

Ammo is extremely limited; more times than not you'll have more enemies to fight than bullets, and the shooting controls are finnicky and unresponsive, making sure you waste ammo on near misses. Enemies also display no evidence of taking damage or how close they are to death, so you won't know how effective you're being until the enemy simply explodes.

The boss fights are the absolute worst. The bosses all have a ridiculous amount of health and all use instant death attacks, full health upgrades or no; Some of them are invincible and require special strategies to defeat, not that it's really possible to tell that they're invincible until you're out of ammo. Boss characters are shamelessly reused multiple times with absolutely no alterations to their mechanics as well. And the final boss doesn't even count; literally a gun turret and a rocket launcher fall out of the god damn sky and you're told to just go to town.

There's no story worth talking about here. You get some half-baked ideas about shared consciousness that goes nowhere, characters that hit their one-note personalities and never grow or change in any conceivable way, a plot concerning a conspiracy and the main character's dead daughter that goes nowhere, plot elements that are introduced, fleshed out, and then promptly abandoned, a main villain who's so cartoonishly evil and overpowered that it's impossible to take him seriously, and in the end, nothing gets accomplished, nobody learns anything, and absolutely no part of the story gets explained or receives any kind of closure whatsoever. To ensure it's as confusing as possible, every location is isolated from the other ones, and there's no clear goal or objective, and the game has no continuity whatsoever.

I don't even mind that it wants to be an action game or a Jason film instead of something that's actually scary, but since it's marketed as a horror game, let me be absolutely clear; There is absolutely nothing in this game that is the least bit frightening. This is just any regular action shooter, just covered in giblets and grotesque imagery. Because that's all you need to do horror. Just give a big guy a chainsaw and everyone will ♥♥♥♥ their pants.

At it's best, the game actually threatens to be entertaining. Some of the gunplay sections can be satisfying when the shooting controls feel like cooperating and you actually have ammo. Enemy heads explode when killed, which never gets old. The crossbow adds an element of strategy and depth to the fights. That's when the game really shines; when you're given a large open level, lots of ammo, and a number of enemies and just told to dispatch them however you like. But then you run straight into an instant kill trap that you had no chance of seeing coming because it had never been introduced before this point and indeed will probably never show up again.

I don't hate the Evil Within, but my experience with the game was largely negative because of the poorly designed mechanics and narrative. There are parts of the game that are fun, but every time you start to have fun it feels like the game punishes you for it.

Basically, if you read the entire review and still feel like that's your cup of tea, go ahead. This game is for you. Otherwise, it's a buggy mess of a game, and your money would be better spent elsewhere.

reviewText:
Don't go into this game with the expectation that you're going to be scared. This game is not something that will keep you scared after you finish playing it. The game will throw a lot of blood and gore at you with scary looking things, but that's the extent of the scare.

What this game is, and what you should go into with the expectation, is an action game with horror elements. There are horror-style monsters, but the game is thoroughly an action game with resource management.

The movements can be a little clunky, and deaths will be frequent on higher difficulties. Buried in the mess, there is a very interesting and thought out story to the game. I am on my second playthrough now, and am enjoying it.

I believe this game got a lot of negative reviews because of the way it was talked up and advertised. It was said to revolutionize" and "reinvent" the survival horror genre. That is not the case. Moving past that
date: this game is a very enjoyable and challenging experience with a cool story and begs for a sequel to answer the loose ends."

Art Design/Graphics

Every new area is made to look unique and significantly different than the other in many different aspects. This makes the game stand out among other beautiful games and helps the pacing of the game. column32: I was able to run most of the game at ~60 fps (when unlocked through the dev console) with my 3GB 660ti and old Phenom II 1055T x6 3.2ghz. Performance and Framerate

Despite the ridiculous system specifications for this game
column32: I was able to run most of the game at ~60 fps (when unlocked through the dev console) with my 3GB 660ti and old Phenom II 1055T x6 3.2ghz. The game runs rather poorly in some beginning sections of the game but otherwise it runs adequately. Never was the framerate unplayable or noticably poor. However if your PC is even a little bit out of date I really recommend upgrading if you want to play this game optimally. I believe the performance hit comes from unoptimised phsyics and a very hefty amount of--rather beautiful--particle effects.\n\nThe game was designed around the 30fps target not because it was "cinematic" but because of the performance target on next-gen consoles as well as the rarity of Japanese developers making games anywhere past 30fps. The game is playable on 60fps but is not recommended due to lack of optimisation (which they announced they are doing for future patches). Personally I did not experience any quirks or bugs with the unlocked framerate. Performance-wise
column33:
this game was no headache.

Aspect Ratio

Another thing many people have been complaining about is the absurdly wide aspect ratio. At first I was definitely skeptical about this
column34: and used the dev console to change it to remove them and instead play in fullscreen. The wide aspect ratio artificially adds a lot of FOV and playing in your native aspect ratio will likely cut most of it off
column35: making it practically unplayable. So I decided to settle with the black bars. After playing the game for a while
column36: you get used it and start to understand why this was a design decision.\n\nFor starters
column37: the extra FOV helps a ton. It also avoids breaking immersion as higher FOV with less-wide aspect ratio causes warping and distortion around your screen. Secondly
column38: the wide aspect ratio is there in order to simulate a cinema-esque experience. No
column39: I'm not talking about the 30 vs 60 fps debate
column40: I'm talking about the difference between watching a film in different aspect ratios. In film
column41: wider aspect ratios allow for wider shot angles and ultimately provide for more beautiful shots without warping the image with higher-fov with a thinner aspect ratio. The wide aspect ratio of this game simulates that difference very well and gives the game a very unique and enriching feel. After finishing the game I can say that there is a legitimate reason for this and I actually like the decision. It is disappointing that 1/3 of your screen isn't displaying anything

reviewText:
So. now that the steam reviews have all but summarized all the technical issues with the game, how about I tell you about the gameplay? Assuming some of you would like to know that kind of information.

I think the best way I can summarize the game play is it's similar to Resident Evil 4, but with the jankiness of the controls that were present in RE 5 and RE 6. There is a lot to like about the game, but in that same vein, there is a lot to hate too.

You can definitely tell this is a Shinji Mikami game. A lot of easter eggs and nods towards old school Resident Evil are here. There is even his common trope with rocket launchers present here too.  I want to talk about the things I liked with the game, and the things I hated. Hopefully, this will be adequate enough.

The Atmosphere is amazing. I was engrossed into the story pretty deeply, even if you can kind of piece it together after the first third of the game. There is no real secret as to who the big bad is, and who is associated with him. Really, the mystery is more along the lines of what caused the big bad to be so bad in the first place. It's very involving.

and well....that's about it really. In terms of all the points, that's the only one I have no problems listing as a positive. everything else could go either way. Allow me to explain why.

The resource management in this game is ultimately less strategic and more frustration. It's fine in the early game. But once you get past chapter 7 the resource management of this game falls apart. See once you start the game, you learn to respect how little you have. The stealth aspects give balance where it's needed. Certain segments can get passed without firing a single shot. It's later on however where that no longer matters. Somewhere in the middle the shark is jumped and there is a focus on hoardes. You are flung into a situation where every enemy is already alerted to your presence. This is a problem, cause all those bullets you hamfisted and tried so dearly to covet are now all dumped into the hoarde. And don't worry; the size of the hoarde makes it real clear that all your bullets are meant for them. After you dump literally all your ammo during one of these segments, you desperately claw around and maybe find a very paltry amount of ammunition, and this is to carry you through another segment where, now you fight a miniboss.

Let me summarize that for you: early game flow is scrounging ammo and stealth segments. mid game is hoardes and minibosses, so you scrounge, dump all your ammo, scrounge again, and do the same thing.  End game is a mix of the two, but primarily the hoarde and boss thing. I just don't see what they were going for here. There is challenge, then there is nonsense. It's nonsensical that you force the player to fight all these overwhelming odds when you try so hard to convince them in the early game this is about making every shot count and using stealth is pivotal. Why on Earth would you throw them into action segments? There is an aspect of balance that is not clicking here, and it isn't fun fighting 10 enemies with 5 pistol bullets, 2 shotgun shells, 2 matches, and a flash bolt. It's just not.

This would be all but alleviated if melee was viable, but melee is not viable, even when you max it out. What could take 12-20 hits unupgraded, gets down graded to 6-10 hits. That's still not adequate, cause it takes forever to deal with one enemy that way. I just don't understand why or where the identity crisis came into play. Do you want me to fight hoardes of enemies and bosses? is that the game you wanted? at the very least, well equip the player before the boss battle. They do on a couple bosses but the remainder? come on. Do you want your game to be stealth-centric and make bullets precious? lower the frequency of hoardes or bosses. I mean... you have struck gold with RE4 Shinji, why on Earth are you taking a page from a game like RE6?

Enough about that though. Hey speaking of RE6, remember that gross FOV with the really terribad janky controls? The Evil Within's title is actually a reference to the controls. Cause my god man. Be prepared for some very janky badness. I don't want to spend too much time talking about it. It's easy to just say they are bad.

Story was kind of covered in atmosphere, but the ending is insulting, if not expected and the only real way to end it really. The story is decent. Again, you have to go in with the mentality of wanting to learn about the villain, not why things are happening.

The game is long as hell though. my first playthrough took 16 hours (I have no idea why it only says 15 hours on record, considering I also am doing a 5 hour run.)

I think I talked about this game enough. I do recommend it, surprisingly. it's not a terrible game. It's ok. It's not worth the hype. Try and wait for a sale.

reviewText:
Great game that finds some middleground between games like Resident evil 4 and Outlast.
The thing about it is that you're not by far as helpless as you should be.  But nonetheless the game offers a great survival experience. The first half of the game is incredibly tense and the game peaks in chapter 9 for suspense. After that it kinda becomes a rollercoaster of action scenes but still enjoyable to me. The biggest problem with the game however is the story or rather the lack of it that is. The first few chapters you're pretty much clueless which is fine and adds to the atmosphere, halfway through the story seemed to become pretty interresting but it just stopped explaining whatever was going on.

The gameplay itself, the unique bossfights are awesome I enjoyed every second playing through the areas.

It has several functions like impale (duh), flash (huh?), explode(ok I guess), freeze (say what?), electrify(oh common), fire(ok that actually is useful considering you want to burn corpses, but what?!?) The upgrade system is fairly simpel and lets you chose how you wanna play the game, so thats a plus most definitly.

All in all I really enjoyed playing the game even though I was expecting a cool twisted story.

reviewText:
Very few games have left me with as many conflicted feeling as The Evil Within. It swings from being a genuinely scary game to feeling like a decent-if-forgettable RE4/5 clone and back again. There are hurdles to jump over in understanding how the gameplay works before you can get into it and then the game never leverages the strengths of that system. There's a creepy element of psychological torment that pervades the game and story, but when it pokes it's  head through the story is, quite frankly, kinda stupid.

The gameplay takes the Resident Evil 4 route, but where Leon Kennedy was a badass and thoroughly capable of handling any situation Sebastian Castellanos is a wuss who's not particularly great with a weapon and whose physical attacks are hit an enemy like a weak gust of wind. You'll quickly find that open combat is a terrible option as enemies are tough and even headshots that blast away large portions of their skull only seem to moderately annoy them. It's easy to burn half your ammo on one enemy. While it's not particularly scary the early sections are like a playground where you slowly stalk enemies and carefully choose your point of attack.

Then you find out the game has an upgrade system. Suddenly you're given a lot of options for improving you physical prowess and the usefullness of your weapons (of which you'll get a small arsenal of) The game begins to force you into open combat more often and it become obvious that ammo conservation isn't important because the game is regulating how much ammo is dropped by enemies and from crates. I just blasted my way through the stealth sections at the end because they're just set in boring corridors that are a pain to navigate carefully though and there's not particular penalty for going rambo through it.

What really saves the game is the middle third of the game which slows down the pace and uses the game's atmoshpere to good effect. You'll traverse torture chambers, crypts, a deserted mansion, and caverns and that pacing, sound design, and enemies just feel right. I constantly felt on the edge of my seat waiting for something horrible to happen.

Then you hit the city and the game loses momentum through to the end. It lacks both the atmosphere of the middle third and the well designed stealth sections of the first third. You're too well equipped and upgraded for the action sequences to feel like a desperate fight for your life or the stealth sections to feel imposing. The big bosses are silly rather than imposing. It's not bad, but it's not the type of horror game that The Evil Within should have been.

If you're a fan of horror games it's worth it to pick up on a sale because when it works The Evil Within works really well and when it fails it's never bad, it's just disappointing. Despite everything I still liked The Evil Within even if I wanted it to be so much more than it was.

Some further thoughts if you're still reading.

- The game is very linear and features little exploration. The idea was to constantly warp you around and keep your bearings off, but I don't think it worked that well although I respect the theory behind it. Interestingly one of the best and creepiest sections is set in a mansion that you have to explore.

- Has a Dark Souls thing going on graphically where most of the architecture of the buildings looks great, but any thing natural looks like doo-doo. There's a part where you walk through a field of sunflowers and the texture on the ground looks like it was ripped from an N64 game.

- Jennifer Carpenter (who played Debra on Dexter) gives one of the most bored and unenthusiastic voice acting performances you'll ever hear in a game. Fortunately she only gets a handful of lines.

- I really like what they did with the RE style save room by making you question the safety that it provides you.

- Textures are constantly loading slowly. Scenes cut to aother angle of things that don't have textures loaded. At one point a gate drops revealing a boss monster whose textures pop onto him a second later.

- (SPOILER ALERT) If you want to be overly analytical about things you could certainly draw parallels between Ruvik's story and the nature of game development when surrounded by corporate culture. How he both has control of his creation taken away from him while simultaneously being trapped by it. As a game developer Shinjo Mikami is both typecast as The Horror Guy" as well as having a lack of ownership over Resident Evil and being forced to watch it taken in directions he may never have intended. Ultimately
date: as this is Mikami's last game in the Director's seat (allegedly) Ruvik is ultimately looking for escape (and to try and scare the ♥♥♥♥ out of Sebastian/The Player along the way.\n\nBut that may just be me looking too deeply into things."

reviewText:
A game...with zombies...
But these zombies aren't your usual zombies. No, they aren't your cuddly, happy-go-lucky, singing zombies. They're brain eating, violent zombies, and some of them can shoot you in the face! Maybe they're not zombies so much as they're mutants. Probably mutants.

Scare Factor!

Overall, so far, the game is spooky. It's not scary, but it's spooky! Nothing has made me jump with fear, but some of the death animations and the graphics overall are spectacular. The camera can be a little bit wonky at times, but that's normal with any third-person title. Those shadows, though, man - those friggin' shadows.

Everything Else

No, I haven't completed the game yet. My game time is accurate, but I know enough about the game to write a review. People whine about game time and reviews all the time, but get over it, you know if you like something or not. I'm recommending it, anyway. The sound design is top notch, the graphics are gorgeous, and it's a great game. It scores rather high on the awesome scale, but it's not the greatest game ever made.

Major complaints.

Camera doesn't always cooperate with what's intuitive to the player, and figuring out the weapon system can be a little tricky. Not that the weapon system is difficult to learn, just kind of tricky at times. Maybe that's built in to make the game harder?

Final Thoughts

Death is cheap and the way things are set up, you'll die a ton of times trying to do something, then you'll get it right and feel like an idiot that you died several times, before getting it right. I find that kind of thing hilarious. The limited ammunition aspect of it plays into the horror aspect, and the mood is right. Even still, as well crafted and beautiful as the game is, with the fantastic sound design and use of lighting and shadows, it's just not that scary.

I'm giving this an 8/10, maybe I set my expectations too high, but that being said, I definitely wasn't disappointed. 2014 was a golden year for games, and this one definitely belongs in the trophy case.

reviewText:
Just finished The Evil Within at about 17 hours total. It's unfortunate that the initial set-up process prior to starting the game is causing so many people to give up on it.

Once you really get into the meat of the campaign it just keeps getting better and better. The enemy and level design in particular were OUTSTANDING! Everything is extremely well balanced in terms of combat and equipment management. You are forced to play conservatively. There are high-octane action sequences on occasion but stealth is absolutely necessary the majority of the time.

What really impresses me in retrospect is the fact that slowly sneaking your way through level after level never became the least bit boring thanks to the insane amount variety in the level design. For an action-horror title I was blown away at how I was consistently excited to see what the next dungeon had in store for me.

I loved how difficult it was, too. Challenging and at times frustrating but always fair and always, ALWAYS stressful (in a good horror kinda way).

Frightening, graphic, action-packed, addictive, and tons of fun.

I loved The Evil Within.

reviewText:
I'm going to write a first impression for the moment, likely to update once I have beaten the game.

Now, to start with, my machine can only really run this game on lower settings. 720p, low shadows, AA off. I cannot attest for the look of the game, I do not care about the look, so long as it is competent and I feel it is. I really wish I could play with shadows on high, because the lighting in this game is phenominal. The only thing I feel is off is the aspect ratio, which is a forced 21:9 and apparently on some resolution settings you get an odd full black box around the screen. I don't get this playing on 720p, but I have seen some experience it. But so far the atmosphere has been enough to keep the odd aspect ratio from really bothering me.

And yes, the game runs at a locked 30 FPS (I'm just barely achieving that consistently, so no complaints there). Apparently you can unlock it to 60, where they promise to fix any issue with that. But any issues involving a fully-unlocked FPS specifically will not be tended to, unfortunately.

In terms of gameplay, it works rather well. I mostly played with a controller, but I tried out the keyboard and it works just fine as far as I can tell. You can rebind keys and even assign an action to multiple keys. The controller has a few predetermined settings, you can't totally change which button does what, but the setup works just fine.

Enemies seem somewhat intelligent, I had one get caught on a fence for some-odd reason, but that was the only instance where the AI seemed poor. There's some stealth elements, because getting overwhelmed or running into traps is the easiest way to get killed. It works for what it is, hide under a bed, in a closet, or just crouch-walk to your next destination, hoping not to get seen. Stealth kills are also a thing, which is great because that saves you on a lot of ammo. There are some parts in the game, however, that force you into combat. So far those sections tend to partner you up with someone, but only if the enemies are coming in large waves.

The weapons in this game seem really damn satisfying though. You can blow off chunks of the zombie-enemy-things, even with the starting pistol. There's a crossbow in the game, and, without giving too much away, it's good. Very good.

As for the story, well, it's pretty nuts. I can't say if it's really good or bad because I'm not at a point where any real explanation has popped up. But it's engaging and interesting to say the least. I can't say it's terribly frightening, though I've played enough survival horror games to build up an immunity to most scares. I am looking forward to playing more, even if it's due to my own morbid curiosity.

Overall, it's a competent title. I'm enjoying it for what it is. It's clear that Shinji Mikami hasn't given up his idea for survival horror, as you can see hints of some of the Resident Evil games in there. Specifically, RE1 and 4. I'm sorry to hear that others have had issues, but I, personally, have not. If you are intruiged by a horror atmosphere and don't mind a couple of oddball, but mostly harmless game design decisions, I'd say this is a good one. If you're hesitant, I wouldn't blame you for waiting for a sale or a patch of some description. I plan on updating this when I get around to actually beating the title, so my opinion may change. We'll see!

reviewText: Too many people are judging this game on its optimization... Or lack there of in this case. Is the game perfect? Absolutely not! But, does that make it a bad game? Far from it! One thing this game nails is its atmosphere. The Evil Within has a very dark and gloomy tone to its environment and it really gives off the sensation that each room you walk into holds something very sinister within it. The art style of the game is also rather impressive and adds greatly to the overall tone of the game... The character models however do not share the same style. While the creatures of The Evil Within look particularly twisted and gruesome, the character models of the human characters are unfortunately rather bland. The voice acting is serviceable but not impressive. I cannot make a full opinion of the story because at the time of this review, I am 7 hours into the game but from what I have played so far, the story plays heavily on the psychological horror aspect of the game, causing players to question what's real and what isn't.\n\nMy feelings about the gameplay of The Evil Within are mostly positive but there is certainly room for improvement. The gunplay feels good and the lack of ammunition and resources is a very welcome return from what players have had to endure with other recent so called Survival Horror" games. The Evil Within is unforgiving with the amount of items that you can find in this world of nightmares and you will find yourself having to count your ammo
date: sneak past enemies and use quick thinking along with using the environment itself in order to survive. The user interface and character movements however are rather clunky and can land you into some serious trouble at times... One thing inparticular I found to be odd is the weapons menu is opened by clicking the right analog stick on an Xbox 360 controller. There have been many occasions where I have shot at an enemy and accidently opened the weapons menu because I clenched the controller when I fired.\n\nOverall
recommended: The Evil Within has its share of problems that need ironing out and the lack of optimization for the PC version is inexcusable. But
hoursPlayed: The Evil Within is definitely a game that needs to be experienced by Survival Horror fans and can help bring the genre back to being something to be feared instead of staying the laughing stock it is now for big budget Horror games."

reviewText:
Did you like Shinji Mikami's Resident Evil 4? How about Silent Hill? How about lots of gore and excellent gunplay? If you answered yes to 1 or more of those questions, I would advise you to check this game out!

I have now completed the game and I can only recommend the game more, the gameplay holds the weight of the overly ambitious story. The combat feels intense and becomes increasingly scary due to your constant lack of resources, the horror isn't stacked on too thick with little to no jump scares throughout but you do always have a feeling of dread as you never know what is coming for you next (this is in part because of the games incredible music and sound design. MANY of the noises the enemies makes are bone chilling and because of very effective lighting effects).

The gunplay is very rewarding and crunchy" as in you can feel the heads limbs and other areas being hit and often exploding (I actually shot an enemy in the face and blew its face clean off with only a hole left in the middle of its head it continued to chase me around).

Now that I have completed the game I still stay true to my opening statement and would recommend this game to anyone looking for a cool new 3rd person shooter or  a very nerve racking and often terrifying survival horror experience!"

reviewText:
I'll update this later after more gameplay but wanted to address some potential issues right away and give some initial thoughts.

CPU INTENSIVE:  I have an i5 64 bit core, 8 gb of RAM and a Radeon graphics card with 2 gb dedicated memory.  This is enough to run 99 percent of games just fine; however, I did have to dumb down the graphics setttings on this to get an adequate frame rate.  To my perspective, the graphics still look great, but I know that some people will dislike this.

FRAME RATE:  A lot has been said about the game dropping frame rate, but in 2 hours of play I have not had that problem.  Of course, I did, as I said above, dumb down the graphics a little.

ENEMY AI:  This will irritate some people because the enemies follow you around when they have no reason to.  You finally escape one room, and the bad guy just follows you into the next one even though he didn't see you.  Now you go about escaping the same guy again.  Make it to the next room?  No worries.  He decides to follow you there, as well.

CONTROLS:  The controls are very basic.  The only problem I had with them is that the CROUCH key is also the same as the HIDE key, so while sneeking around I did on a couple of occasions accidentally hide.  I strongly suggest going into the settings and changing crouch to toggle so you don't have to hold <L Control> all day.  One more thing on the controls, I have yet to throw a bottle and stun an enemy.  I always miss.  The aiming for this particular feature is a bit bizzare, so I just use the bottles to cause distractions.

GAMEPLAY:  Well, there's a small intro section and then you are thrown right into it, hiding and running from a chainsaw wielding gimp.  The gameplay is very challenging.  You will die, and you will spend a lot of time hoping the gimp will turn around and go elsewhere, and then hobbling across rooms in the split second he's not looking.  Definitely a traditional third-person horror experience.

OVERALL:  So far I am enjoying the game, though I've been a bit nit-picky above.  So far it seems like a buy if you like third-person horror games with a lot of stealth features.
