reviewText:
Completely overrated, in my opinion. I am a fan of horror games, in particular the Silent Hill style that is written all over Evil Within, but let me be brief and list the shortcomings that didn't make this game work for me.
1) The engine: the controls and precision of strikes/shooting in fights is a real shame. Given that it is a checkpoint game where you have to replay extended stretches of it if you get killed, it is extremely annoying when I get killed regularly because of the controls. In the fights, there is no sense in the way the protagonist acts. He can't use the knife that he carries in melee, only in stealth. He finds himself with his back to an enemy _all the time_ after punching or shooting. The camera angle in the fights doesn't make any sense either, with the enemies frequently ending up in your blind zone when they come close. And yep, you can stuff an enemy with bullets, then lose sight of him, and next moment he stubs you to death with one swift motion or cuts you in pieces. The whole fight dynamics were not making any sense to me. And like I said, when applied to boss fights, I had enough of playing for 5-10 minutes after a checkpoint to collect a weapon or ammo, get to the boss, do precisely what I need to do (say, shoot a bolt), see the camera losing the angle, furiously rotate the protagonist to get hold of the boss, get cut into pieces in the next second, replay 5-10 minutes after the checkpoint, rinse and repeat. Senseless.
2) The story, with all the pretense of the Silent Hill genre, does not grip.
3) I haven't experienced any game killing bugs, but had a few minor ones that just puzzled me. Like, I would start the game, load a checkpoint, and suddenly all game controls are empty. I can't move. Luckily, it's very easy to reset the controls to default, but the question is, what the hell has just happened? Why does it happen? Or take the intentional gameplay controls that are not intuitive and have to be googled up (such as, you press space to examine" and can't find how to turn it off until you google up that you need to press "c"). Like
date: what has just happened? Why is it designed this way?\nIt's merely an ok pastime game if you got it on a major discount. I would be frustrated if I bought in presale and/or at the full price. The trailer was cinematic

reviewText:
YOU WILL SUFFER

Man, I sure wish the game had told me that at the beginning, rather than almost at the end. Truer words were never spoken my friends.

The Evil Within is unfun, unfair, and a terrible experience all around. Also, it doesn't have an original bone in its entire body.

This is what you get when you liberally take elements from Silent Hill, Resident Evil, Clocktower, Outlast, The Last of Us, The Grudge, Texas Chainsaw Massacre, SAW, and Inception and you mix them together with very little regard for what actually made those things GOOD, into a chaotic, disconnected, amorphous ‘plot’ that makes no damn sense until the very end of the game.

If the intention was to make me want to play and watch other things, well, you succeeded. Most of the source material this game draws from is FAR better.

The bottom line is that TEW doesn’t really know what it is and this lack of coherent gameplay direction or even a coherent narrative makes the resulting game a big goopy mess. It wants to be survival horror, but it’s too action oriented for that. It wants to be a good action game, but it randomly throws you against invincible enemies that can instantly kill you with no warning that you must run from.

It wants to be scary, but it just isn’t.

Heed my warnings folks. Here there be monsters, but they aren't the kind you'll enjoy pitting yourself against. This game is just BAD. Stay far away.

reviewText:
This is the second game in my life where I cheated on the first playthrough. Only because I payed some freaking money for it I wanted to see the end of it, no matter what. And - admittedly - the gory and brutal gameplay can indeed keep the fun above the bare minimum needed for an action horror title to keep me going. Unfortunately, that's about it when it comes to the positive aspects of the game. The negative outweigh the positive by far.

Take the story, for example. To be honest, I didn't even understand what the game was trying to tell me. There simply is no real story, it's a strange mix of involuntary brain surgery and drug induced nightmare fantasy hotchpotch ... thingy. And it is the inconceivably thin layer of background for the strange creatures (and your two companions) and their even stranger actions that is supposed to keep you motivated for about 14 hours - I call an epic fail, Mr. Mikami.

Secondly, the game mechanic for character and weapon development is total crap - you collect puddles or jars of green gel to buy weapon and character upgrades. Because that's the way the world beyond our consciousness works, we turn snot to ammo pouches...?! WTF?! What is wrong with dead enemies dropping some good old coins, for heavens sake?

Next annoying feature" are the doors (yes

reviewText:
My initial impressions of this game was one of bewilderment. The story is shrouded in mystery and it will be slowly unraveled throughout your playthrough, but it won't explain anything outright. This may be frustrating, but I challenged myself to embrace not only the challenge of the game, but also the challenge of figuring out what the heck is going on; it is fun to devise your own theories.

The gameplay shines because you have many options with which to approach a situation. Oftentimes you can forgo battle altogether, but I found stealth-killing the most satisfying. One of the game's biggest strength is in its level-variety and gameplay-variety. The designers put you in a variety of gameplay-scenarios so that you don't feel like you're doing the same thing over and over again, and the same applies to the levels.

At first, I was not really into the game; it didn't make sense, and it was more weird and gross, rather than scary. After reaching a point where more freedom was given however, I started to like the game. I began learning how its mechanics worked, and dying over and over again would only encourage me to try different things and be more explorative. Soon I would come back for more regularly. There was something enthralling about how all its parts worked together, from the haunting save-mirror song Claire De Lune, its finely polished gameplay, to its mysterious and curious plot.

reviewText:
Fans of Shinji Mikami rejoice as this is the Resident Evil you wanted (not 6!). Instant kill bosses, varied and hard enemy fodder and limited ammunition. These aren't the slow-poke enemies like before, so to help, the game gives you the ability to sneak, distract and assasinate (up close, with some enemies only).

The issue with the game is technical, for PC standards. First the splash video crashes the game which you can fix with launch options and the fps is limited to 30.

The PC master race does not approve of a fps cap (after all, we spent a boat load on our pcs to avoid that crap cap!).

Most of these can fixed with these launch options:

+com_skipIntroVideo 1 +r_swapinterval -1

But then you run into heavy optimization issues with stuttering etc... but I don't believe that should deter you from the game. If you like Outlast and especially earlier resident evils, this is the game for you!

reviewText:
OK, start with the topics most are complaining about, the aspect ratio and the frame rate. Unlock the frame rate (if your PC up to it) but it still has issues. I’m not defending this as the game looks amazing in 60fps… however it’s not optimized for it.
Second, the requirements are higher than needed. I have a decent system (i-7 4770 OC’ed 4.5ghz, ASUS GTX 780 OC’ed, 16GB 2133 RAM (corsair Vengeance), ASUS Maximus formula board corsair 860i PSU and 3 Samsung 840 PROs in RAID5) now let’s face facts quality of components does play a part. I’m playing in 30fps at 1440 on my 50 inch TV (that’s why I’m not ganna complain about the bars, however on a smaller monitor id be a bit ♥♥♥♥♥♥ as well.
Ok, ok… the game. Well it’s awesome… ever chapter is challenging in its own right, and they each have their own theme. The game make you feel helpless at time 9just what you want from survival horror). The menu upgrade system weapons all fit and feel good.
The graphics- Well it could be better definitely needs some better AA. The textures are good sometimes and bad in other, but overall not bad. The lighting is defiantly beautiful.
The game play is fun and adds just enough handicap to make you crap when your low on ammo and walk into a room with 3 damned waiting for you. The bosses are just simply bad ♥♥♥ and tricky.
The overall theme… I am truly pumped, while the game doesn’t add any ground breaking features it does pull all the elements together for a truly fun experience.
The story, while I haven’t beat the game (currently on chapter 10), there is a good story here you just need to read into it. Look for all the audio logs and read all documents pay attention to the cut scenes and the character you run into, I so far love the angle the game is taking. I have heard the ending is disappointing, however this maybe from people not paying attention to all the clues leading up (just an opinion as I feel the story is good thus far).
Can’t wait to beat the game and play again aiming for the 5hr play though. I use to love and play resident evil 1 back in the day, but the series has taken a turn for the worse (5+) but now the evil within is filling the shoes. Loving it!
The game has thrills, chills, action, story, motivation, puzzles, mystery, bad ♥♥♥ boss battles, and is one hell of a mind trip.
If I scored before finishing the game it is easy 8.5 out of 10.
Pick it up, make sure you play though chapter 3 to get a good feel of diversely.

reviewText:
This game isn't 100% horror as apparently many people expected it to be, but I still found it to be an excellent addition to the survival horror genre.

Though there are more action oriented segments than I would like, the moments where the game is focused on horror and suspense are brilliant. I was honestly on edge for most of the game, which is something that I haven't really experienced in a long time. Not only are the enemies uniquely grotesque and genuinely scary (especially when they surprise you) but the dark environments truly set the mood and add an extra layer of dread and suspense. The lighting, in particular, was amazing in my opinion. Not only that, but the sound effects were also incredibly well made; making me cringe everytime I heard the ghastly noises from enemies nearby, always hoping that they had not seen or heard me moving about.

The story itself was fascinating to me. The simple fact that the game takes place in the mind of a psycopath and that you have to fight through his evil subconscious to escape made this game compelling enough for me in and of itself. The added details (such as the major characters and backstories) made everything that much better. Sadly most of the characters in the game aren't developed enough, especially when it comes to main character Sebastian. Though we do get a better sense of him through collectibles, his in-game personality doesn't reflect his backstory well enough. He's pretty boring in person, to be honest. That being said, I still ended up appreciating each of the characters and their personalities even though they weren't as fleshed out as I would have liked. They inevitably made the story more interesting and compelling.

One other component that I liked about the game's narrative is the mystery surrounding it. The game never tells you the complete story. It tells you the main details but then gives you small pieces of information via collectibles and audio logs to make sense of the particulars. This was something that I truly enjoyed since it allowed me to make connections between all the pieces of information the game made available to me in order to figure out what was going on in the background. I was already invested in the story as it is, but this facet of the game incentivized me to dive into it even more.

Overall I would say that this was an awesome gaming experience. The Evil Within is definitely near the top of my list of greatest games to come out in 2014, and I'm definitely looking forward to play the DLC chapters. GET THIS GAME!!!

reviewText:
The Evil Within is one of the best horror games I've ever played, with a clear emphasis on the word 'games'.

No matter how much scarier you think other games might be, the fact remains that this one provides much more variety and depth in its gameplay. Also, it generally does a better job of tying in scares with level design and gameplay mechanics, not to mention that 'scares' alone are highly subjective and rarely a factor in replayability (i.e. you might as well just watch a movie if all you want is to see/hear really creepy stuff).

Speaking of subjective factors, I liked the story - even its main protagonist. Yes, there are cheesy moments here and there, but overall it does a good job of ♥♥♥♥ing with your mind and keeping you guessing. And perhaps more importantly, everything is presented in a very polished and atmospheric setting, with plenty of morbid details to keep you immersed and uneasy.

It is ultimately a linear experience, but exploration is rewarded with both items and story bits. And as I've already hinted at, this game offers multiple, organic approaches to solving each encounter and is therefore highly replayable, especially in new game+ mode. I rarely felt like there were a fixed number of  options, pre-determined  by the developers. It always felt more like a creative survival effort - tense and satisfying.

I don't remember the last time a horror game kept me hooked for more than 7 hours straight, and I have played quite a few of them: the amnesia games, among the sleep, silent hill, resident evil, etc.

Of course, there are some issues with the game:
-too expensive in my opinion
-poorly optimized (especially considering the price they are charging on PC - thankfully most of the issues can be fixed)
-low fov
-giant black bars
-'cinematic' camera angles can mess up your gameplay occasionally
-a few crappy encounters with gun-wielding zombies... seriously don't ever do that again

reviewText:
First a little back ground..  I am a proud member of the PC Master Race, running dual 7970's in x-fire; I love my high end PC gaming.  Resident Evil 4 is also my favorite game of all time.  On with the review..

Chapter 1:  PC Optimization?

The Dev created Evil Within with this wonky FOV and in letterbox supposedly as a design choice.  Well it was the wrong one.  The FOV makes it more difficult than it should be to play.  Regarding the 30 FPS lock, while this is terrible to do to us PC Elite's, for this type of game its no big deal.  that said, you can change this via console commands, and hopefully Bathesda will patch and fix it properly.  I had to disable X-fire on my rig to get this to run, again, sucks, but no big deal.  It's a console game for Christ's sake and runs like as dream on one of my 7970's.  So my thoughts on the PC Port are:  It runs like it would if you had it for the PS4, and that's ok.  At least we have access to the game at all on PC.

Chapter 2:  The game itself

I think the game is great.  If you slapped Leon in the main role and replaced the enemies with the Ganado's from RE4 this could be called RE 4.5.  The game play, aside from the horrible FOV is the same as RE4, and I think that's awesome.  Im having a great time with it and cant wait to play it again.  At the end of the day that's all we can ask for with a new game, Right?  If you have any interest in the game, or the survival horror genre in general.  Get it...

reviewText:
A spiritual successor to Resident Evil 4. The game is often times a great challenge without ever being BS or artificially difficult. The levels are seperated by chapter, and are very linear with minimal backtracking. Many boss fights are meant to be escaped instead of fought. Weapons are satisfying and enemies react very noticeably to being attacked, making gunplay feel heavy and strong (provided you have ammo to burn at all.)

The first quarter of the game felt really easy but after that the game starts sending increasingly large waves of enemies per chapter, putting a heavy focus on combat and managing resources. I nearly ran out of ammo completely a few times but was always able to make using traps or disposable melee weapons. Also most guns have the capability of killing most enemies in a single critical shot if you feel lucky.

Also a few things the games did right that could have been annoying but wasn't.
-AI partners: they are for brief sections and can easily handle themselves, and can be healed for free. They are surprisingly usefull, while in most games AI partners are a drag to bring with you.
-Puzzles: They are all short-medium length and require just the right amount of thought. No reading books to find where a secret pressure plate is or anything like that.
-Length: The game took me 18 hours to beat on my first playthough on survival and I apparently found only about 60% of the collectibles. The game is very replayable and offers rewards for doing side content like hard mode and collectibles.

I played with an Xbox One controller at the default 30fps and the game felt great to me. The optimizations is pretty off, I have a GTX970 and wasn't able to keep a steady 60fps when I switched the cap off, although I can play Rage and Wolfenstein maxed with better performance. I have never experienced any crashes or game breaking glitches.
I was at first saying I was glad I didn't pre-order, but buying the game I feel like I would have been happy if I did, it's a great game despite the lack of true PC care.

reviewText:
I wanted to like The Evil Within for its terrific art & atmosphere, and am okay with some of the gripes summed up by Kotaku (1. accumulation of horror tropes, 2. lack of story development), but yet another ragequit later due to deficient controls and painful environment interaction, I abandon.

Why oh why, dear Sebastian-being-chased-by-five-barbedwired-zombies, does button A makes you merrily pick up a random bottle on the floor (and dying from hatchets in the neck) instead of climbing the !@#$ obstacle I want you to climb? Why do you feel so clumsy in your movements? Playing Evil Withing after a fluid TPS experience like Splinter Cell Blacklist or Spec Ops: The Line feels like it's 1996 again. Even Max Payne 3 and its occasional bug was less infuriating.

Why, Mikami-san, these unpredictable no-return points forcing me to load a previous save in order to finish exploring a chapter I had barely scratched?

Why, Mikami-san, maintaining the crappy tradition of a save system that lets you basically save at any time but in a clunky way, which has neither the convenience of PC-style save-with-a-keypress, nor the immersion factor of no manual saves but more regular save points?

I wish masters like Mikami put more effort into evolving their recipe, and I wish Bethesda did more playtesting.

reviewText:
For people who'd rather watch what I'm about to say, here's a spot-on review done by Yahtzee.
http://www.escapistmagazine.com/videos/view/zero-punctuation/9840-The-Evil-Within-Review

Yep, agreed with almost everything in that clip but here's what I'd like to emphasize:

Pros:
+The design of the environments is immersive and, for the most part, eerie.
+The game starts out scary and intriguing.
+The boss battles are original and require you to figure out weaknesses and think quickly.

Cons:
-The immersiveness of the environments drop away because you keep getting inexplicably teleported between areas.
-The game becomes less scary and intriguing when you get a CROSSBOW THAT SHOOTS EXPLOSIVE AND SHOCK BOLTS.  WHAT?!?!?!
- In regard to the last point, this game is not survival horror, it's action horror.
-The once original boss battles come back again and again and become repetitive.
-The goalposts for beating bosses change throughout the game.
-The story is left open for interpretation (but in all reality it seems like they just didn't try hard enough).

In the end I just wanted to finish it to say I did.  By the time I reached the final boss battle I was happy that it was basically an arcade shooter (complete with big red targets to show you where the boss' weak point is) so I didn't have to exert any more effort on this title.

6/10 - I wanted to like it so much but after the first few chapters things start going downhill.
